page_analysis.text_content:
Daylight
plane

The daylight plane in
conjunction with the
setbacks & height
limits, create an
invisible tent

intended to contain
development on the lot
in a way that preserves
privacy and exposure to
natural light.

Code sections
Page 26
18.12.040 (a) Table 2
Page 27
18.04
Page 28
18.12.040 (c) Table 2
Page 29
18.12.050 (b) (2)
18.12.040 (j)

26

Primary daylight plane (sides)

The primary daylight plane regulates structures located within the buildable area.
Structures located in the rear and/or side yards are regulated by the accessory-
structure daylight plan described on the next page.

Fig 20 Front elevation showing side primary daylight plane

Side lot line

10′ from
average
grade

Average grade

Grade at the nearest point
on the adjacent lot

Existing grade of the structure
(at midpoint of wall)

Max. allowed is
Min. required by
Building Code

45°

Notes:
• Daylight plane is measured from average grade.
• Average grade is established using existing
grade—before any grading or fill (See Fig 44 p. 42)
• Side daylight plane is measured (up) at lot line.
• Rear daylight plane is measured (up) at rear setback.

Side lot line

24′ max. for protrusions

*
Max. building height

visual_elements.description: A conceptual diagram of an 'invisible tent' representing the daylight plane, shown as a wireframe rectangular prism with a sloped top.

A cross-sectional elevation diagram illustrating the 'side primary daylight plane' in relation to two residential structures and the ground. It shows a sloped line originating from the side lot line, indicating the daylight plane. Key measurements and angles are annotated. The diagram includes two houses, ground lines (average grade, grade at nearest point on adjacent lot, existing grade of structure), and vertical lines representing lot lines and building height limits. Dashed lines indicate the daylight plane and maximum building height.

technical_specifications.parameter: Daylight plane origin height from average grade

sections: Primary daylight plane (sides) (right column main content)
Fig 20 Front elevation showing side primary daylight plane (figure caption)

additional_notes: Page number '26' is present at the bottom left.
The asterisk (*) next to 'Max. building height' in the diagram is not explained on this page, suggesting a potential legend or further explanation elsewhere.
cross_references: accessory-structure daylight plan described on the next page.
Fig 44 p. 42 (referenced in Notes section for average grade establishment)
